title:
Comparison of Solar Cell Efficiencies of Black Phosphorus and Silicon at
  the Nano and Micro Scales from First-Principles Calculations
abstract:
Density functional theory and many-body (GW+BSE) calculations of
transmittance, absorbance, and reflectance are performed on silicon and black
phosphorus (BP). We find that a damping value of 0.01 used in the dielectric
function calculation is the optimal for calculating the solar cell efficiency
of Si. Our calculations indicate that the solar cell efficiency of a 100 {\mu}m
thick Si slab is 27.4% while the efficiency of BP for the same thickness is
2.33% and 1.94% for light polarized along the zigzag and armchair directions,
respectively. For 100 nm thick materials, we obtain that Si presents a 0.8%
solar cell efficiency and BP exhibits a 0.14% and 1.02% efficiency for light
polarized along the the zigzag and armchair directions, respectively,
indicating that BP performs better than Si at these small scales. Our results
underscore the important effect of the material thickness on solar cell
efficiencies.
